{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2981442,"name":"Martin Pirringer","username":"mpirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T17:02:59.121Z","cooked":"

Made me a vise for making connectors out of stuff lying around and some 3dp

`

20211213_11323714624×2604 2.52 MB

First some captive nuts in some gears
20211213_11245012604×4624 1.15 MB

some more 3dp stuff the vise body with one of the plates installed
20211213_11275312604×4624 1.07 MB

Both sides installed this plates are for xt60
20211213_11310512604×4624 1.09 MB

With 2 XT60 females ready to receive wires.
This was a first attempt with using heat threat inserts in plastic (HIPS). Worked ok. Easy to mess up when you dont put the iron on perfectly straight so nuts are easier. maybe there is a jig for that coming too.
Hardware requied.
Some inserts and bolts (M5 used in this case). The main bolts are 5/16 so the cutout in the gears is for 5/16 nuts
Plastic HIPS but most any will work. Printed with a .8 nozzle .4mm layer height .88 outside perimeter 1.3 inside perimeter width 5 perimeters 10% infill 8 bottom 8 top layers.

Designed in inventor - inventor files and STL here

grabcad.com

`

`

Does the math work out on the melting points for this to hold up to soldering temperatures?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T17:19:57.630Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":47.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398096,"topic_slug":"vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws/398096/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981446,"name":"Martin Pirringer","username":"mpirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T17:30:13.771Z","cooked":"

I am not putting the solder iron on the Vise. HIPS like ABS holds its form well to about 120 C I know solder is above that but if you do it right then the solder iron does not touch the vise but the pegs of the connectors sticking up. The shell of an xt60 is Nylon and that too would start deforming at about 140C or many other connectors like the HT series and all .100 spaced or mostly ABS on the shells. So you cant touch the connector shell with a solder iron anyway. And for the real small connectors pins crimp on. This is mostly for bigger stuff like the XT series, DIN type and the bigger amp connectors so basically Non crimpers above 2 amps. So for motor connectors

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T17:30:13.771Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":61.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398096,"topic_slug":"vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws","display_username":"Martin Pirringer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28019,"username":"s-neff","name":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor "},"post_url":"/t/vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws/398096/3","custom_user_title":"Mentor ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981454,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T19:01:03.183Z","cooked":"

The nylon can start to soften during soldering, where it’s in contact with the cups/contacts. If the contacts are touching the hips, I would be worried about the hips starting to melt onto and insulate the contacts. If the hips is touching the nylon, the design should work great.

^

I’ve had some cheap, plastic jaw vises that start to deform somehow while soldering XT60s, touching only the housing. HIPS should be fine though.

20211213_16260312604×4624 1.33 MB
20211213_16280212604×4624 1.37 MB

Seems to be working for me did 2 motors and no damage to the vise and yeah I messed up one connector put on a female instead of a male. So I did 3 so far. Maybe cause the perimeter walls are almost 6mm thick so a lot of plastic to heat and deform. I would not make this out of PLA though.

And yeah I always have a male and female plugged into each other when doing the soldering prevents the pins from going crooked when you leave the solder iron on too long

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T21:43:22.552Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":114,"readers_count":113,"score":47.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398096,"topic_slug":"vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws","display_username":"Martin Pirringer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/0/0/00b42e15b4161d6db7922dd26eba0d180731f845.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/e/c/ecdc3d1665ed9a4a81e35c95551fcdbdb955c256.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28019,"username":"s-neff","name":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor "},"post_url":"/t/vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws/398096/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981472,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T21:52:53.305Z","cooked":"
mpirringer:

I always have a male and female plugged into each other when doing the soldering prevents the pins from going crooked when you leave the solder iron on too long

I found this is pretty much mandatory when soldering to connectors where the pins have low thermal mass or the pins are not held in something like a glass block.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T21:52:53.305Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":102,"readers_count":101,"score":90.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398096,"topic_slug":"vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vise-for-connectors-with-interchangeable-jaws/398096/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981687,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-15T04:18:02.365Z","cooked":"

Nice.

I use what I found out is now called the “plate press” method for getting inserts in perpendicular. I insert them in the hole and stop just short of flush and take the part and press it down on a table top or other flat surface to seat the insert straight and flush. It doesn’t work for all part shapes and geometries so you just have to develop the touch to drive them in as straight as you can and with just enough force to seat them and not push them through the part. It’s sort of like teaching students to drill perpendicular holes with a portable drill; “straight, straighter, straighter, even more straighter…”.

Having a set of insert ends for your soldering iron like https://www.amazon.com/Compatible-Heat-Set-Installation-Inserts-Connecting/dp/B08LQTD21D helps a lot. If you’ve got a lathe, it’s a quick and useful lathe project. I made mine and occasionally whip up another one for some special situations where you might need more reach or the like.

That vise does look like a cool project!
